title: UBS Is a Tough Act for Credit Suisse to Follow
sub_head: Despite similar business models, the two Swiss wealth managers have key differences that investors shouldn’t gloss over
body:
UBS ’s strong results, despite an unexpected Archegos loss, contrast sharply with those of crisis-hit crosstown rival Credit Suisse . On paper the banks are similar, but investors can expect UBS to stay ahead.
On Tuesday, the world’s largest wealth manager surprised markets with a $774 million loss related to the collapse of the U.S. hedge fund. But the hit shouldn’t distract investors from the overall picture: The bank grew revenues, profits and assets under supervision, generating a healthy annualized return on tangible equity of 14%.
At first glance, UBS and Credit Suisse appear similar. Both combine a profitable Swiss universal bank with a sizable wealth management business that also provides clients with investment banking and asset management. UBS is only slightly larger in terms of total assets, $1.1 trillion versus $0.93 trillion.
Yet Credit Suisse has shown itself to be a riskier operator. This is clear from the numbers it reports as well as its disproportionate exposure to Archegos and other recent blowups.
Credit Suisse has higher “risk-weighted” assets, despite its smaller total assets, implying that those assets it does hold are deemed riskier by regulators. Moreover, Credit Suisse’s first-quarter “value-at-risk” or VAR—a metric that estimates the amount that could be lost in a given day—was $67 million, versus just $11 million for UBS. Admittedly, direct VAR comparisons are complicated by different calculation methods and confidence levels: UBS uses a 95% confidence level whereas Credit Suisse’s is 98%.
